title: Amazon Prime gifting mechanism
prompt: Amazon wants to increase Prime subscriptions through a gifting mechanism — let existing Prime members gift 3-month trials to friends/family. The hypothesis: gifting converts better than free trials because of social proof. You're the PM. Design the experience and prove the hypothesis.
problemDefinition: Conversion tradeoff: social proof may help, but gifting adds friction
Risk of abuse and low-quality signups if incentives are wrong
Need to prove causal lift over the existing free-trial funnel

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Interview gifters and recipients to map motivations before building flows.

options.label: Define wedge
options.text: Pick a wedge (e.g., family accounts) and focus the gifting UX there.

options.label: Ship fast
options.text: Launch a simple gift flow this week and measure conversion.

options.label: Experiment loop
options.text: Define activation (gift redeemed) and run A/B tests to lift it.

questions.text: Where do you place the gift entry point?

options.label: Checkout
options.text: Inject gifting at checkout when intent is high.

options.label: Prime hub
options.text: Make it a Prime benefit in the membership dashboard.

options.label: Email/social
options.text: Use shareable invites and email nudges to scale gifting.

options.label: Ship everywhere
options.text: Put gifting everywhere and let data tell us where it works.

options.label: Value lift
options.text: Does social proof actually increase conversion vs free trials?

options.label: Strategic fit
options.text: Is gifting the right wedge or just a gimmick?

options.label: Speed
options.text: If we wait, competitors will copy and win the gifting space.

options.label: Activation
options.text: Gift redemption is the true activation moment; without it, nothing matters.

theSplit.question: Should Amazon optimize the gifting UX first or optimize the conversion funnel end-to-end?

sides.reasoning: If gifting feels awkward or unclear, the funnel never starts. Fix the wedge first.
The funnel metrics will show the leverage points faster than interviews.
If social proof doesn't actually lift conversion, the UX doesn't matter.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Validate the value lift before building a fancy gifting flow
cagan.spicyQuote: If gifting doesn't beat the free-trial baseline, you're just adding friction and calling it innovation.
breakdown: Value risk: does social proof actually increase conversion?
Usability risk: gifting flows can be clunky and confusing
Viability risk: fraud and abuse could erase gains
The best companies test the hypothesis before scaling the UX
solution: Run a controlled experiment against free-trial baseline
Use a minimal gifting flow with clear attribution
Validate lift in conversion and paid retention
Only then invest in full UX and distribution
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster will ship a gifting flow without proving lift and call it learning. Lenny will optimize the funnel, but if the core hypothesis is wrong, it's wasted. Doshi wants a wedge, but the wedge must still prove value. Torres's discovery is good, but needs a hard go/no-go test.

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map gifting motivations before building the flow
torres.spicyQuote: If we don't understand why people would gift Prime, we can't design a flow that feels natural.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (conversion + retention lift)
Map opportunities: gifting motivations, recipient trust, redemption friction
Weekly touchpoints with gifters and recipients
Test opportunity branches before scaling
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Interview both gifters and recipients weekly
Prototype gifting messages and redemption flows
Run experiments tied to specific opportunity branches
torres.disagreement: Cagan's value-risk framing is aligned, but this needs continuous evidence, not a one-time test. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship without understanding gifting motivations and misinterpret the data. Doshi's wedge is fine once the opportunity space is mapped, not before.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Pick the highest-leverage gifting wedge and win it
doshi.spicyQuote: If gifting is a wedge, treat it like one. If it's not, don't pretend a funnel can save it.
breakdown: This is a strategy question disguised as a UX tweak
Opportunity cost: a broad gift flow could dilute Prime value
Pre-mortem the failure modes: abuse, awkward gifting, low redemption
Pick the wedge with maximum social proof impact
solution: Identify the most natural gifting context (family, holidays)
Design the wedge experience end-to-end
Run a pre-mortem and define wedge success criteria
Expand only if the wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will spend too long validating without picking a wedge. Execution AI Monster will ship everywhere and learn nothing. Lenny will optimize the funnel, but if gifting is the wrong wedge, the loop is wrong.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Optimize the activation loop: gift sent to gift redeemed
lenny.spicyQuote: The whole loop is gift sent → gift redeemed → paid conversion. Find the friction and kill it.
breakdown: Define activation: gift redeemed within 7 days
Map the loop: gifter sends -> recipient redeems -> trial uses -> paid
Benchmark against referral programs
Run weekly experiments to lift redemption
solution: Instrument the gifting funnel end-to-end
Run experiments on copy, incentives, and reminders
Scale the highest-lift variant
Double down on the loop that improves paid conversion
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants to map opportunities, but the data will show the friction points faster. Cagan's hypothesis testing is good, but you can run it via experiments. Doshi's wedge is fine, but you still need the loop to work. Execution AI Monster is fast, but speed without measurement is noise.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship a gifting flow this week and let data decide
exec.spicyQuote: If it takes you a month to design a gifting flow, you're already late. Ship it now.
breakdown: Building is discovery — ship to learn
Gifting is cheap to test in production
Speed beats perfect UX
Kill losers fast and iterate
solution: Launch a simple gifting flow in days
Expose to 10% of Prime members
Review metrics daily
Iterate weekly based on live data
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be interviewing while we could have real conversion data. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but if you wait for benchmark data, you miss the moment. Ship, measure, repeat.

premortem: Redemption flop: gifts are sent but recipients never redeem
Fraud spike: bad actors abuse gift trials and inflate costs
Conversion mirage: redemption rises but paid conversion doesn't
vitalQuestion: Does gifting create a measurable conversion lift over free trials for Prime?
